光圈优先模式：终极指南首先出现在数码摄影学校上。它的作者是库纳尔·马尔霍特拉 (Kunal Malhotra) 。

什么是光圈优先模式？如何使用它来拍摄曝光良好的艺术图像？

在本指南中，我将解释您需要了解的有关光圈优先的所有信息，包括：

  • 什么时候有用（以及什么时候应该避免）
  • 光圈优先与其他常见相机模式（如快门优先）的区别
  • 如何在使用光圈优先时调整相机设置
  • 如何处理常见的光圈优先模式场景

因此，如果您准备好控制您的相机并成为设置大师，那么让我们开始吧！

什么是光圈优先模式？

光圈优先模式，通常表示为“A”或“Av”模式，让摄影师控制光圈和ISO ，同时相机选择相应的快门速度。

换句话说，您可以根据艺术和图像质量问题来确定理想的光圈和 ISO。然后您的相机将选择产生曝光良好、细节丰富的图像的快门速度。

光圈优先是一种半自动相机模式。它不能完全控制相机变量，但可以让您调整几个关键设置（即光圈和 ISO）。它旨在提供灵活性和速度；这样，您就可以专注于主题、构图和艺术性，同时相机优化曝光。

光圈优先模式变量：光圈、快门速度和 ISO

如果将相机设置为光圈优先模式，您可以立即控制光圈和 ISO，同时相机控制快门速度 - 但这些不同的设置提供什么，为什么它们很重要？

光圈、快门速度和 ISO 共同构成曝光三角。通过调整这三个变量中的任何一个，您就可以调整生成图像的曝光（即亮度）。但是，当您使用光圈优先模式时，相机会通过更改快门速度来自动补偿光圈和 ISO 调整（目的是创建准确的曝光）。

因此，如果扩大光圈，相机就会提高快门速度以补偿更亮的曝光。如果降低 ISO，相机会降低快门速度以补偿较暗的曝光。合理？

底线是：使用光圈优先时，即使您调整光圈和 ISO，您的相机也会始终尝试保持良好的曝光。

但你可能会想：如果光圈和ISO不能调节曝光，那我为什么要改变光圈呢？为什么我要更改 ISO？这两种设置为我提供了什么？

光圈和 ISO 产生三个关键效果：

  1. 通过加宽或缩小光圈，您可以调整景深（即对焦的图像量）。大光圈（例如，f/1.8）会产生非常薄的焦平面，因此大部分图像都会模糊。窄光圈（例如，f/16）会产生非常深的焦平面，因此整个场景保持清晰。
  2. 通过增加或减少 ISO，您可以调整图像中的噪点级别。噪点表现为颜色和光线的微小斑点，它会掩盖图像细节 - 因此，通过保持较低的 ISO，您可以最大限度地提高图像质量。
  3. 通过调整光圈或ISO，您可以强制相机改变快门速度。快速快门速度对于捕捉动作场景（例如，飞行中的鸟类或移动中的篮球运动员）至关重要，并且通过扩大光圈和/或提高 ISO，可以使相机提高快门速度。慢快门速度对于捕捉美丽的长时间曝光效果至关重要，通过缩小光圈和/或降低 ISO，可以让相机降低快门速度。

因此，通过调整光圈优先模式下的设置，您可以提高图像质量，添加漂亮的景深效果，甚至创造一些长时间曝光的艺术效果。

第四个变量：曝光补偿

正如我上面强调的，光圈优先模式告诉您的相机在处理其他图像变量时设置曝光（通过调整快门速度）。一般来说，相机会做得很好，你会得到漂亮、详细的曝光。

但相机曝光表并不完美，有时您应该故意使图像曝光过度或曝光不足（通常分别在拍摄非常亮的场景和非常暗的场景时）。

现在，您无法通过更改光圈、ISO 或快门速度来调整曝光。在光圈优先模式下，快门速度设置被锁定，光圈和 ISO 设置的变化将自动通过快门速度的变化来抵消。

这就是为什么相机提供另一种设置，称为曝光补偿。曝光补偿通常用加号 (+) 和减号 (-) 符号表示，它可让您指示相机提高或降低快门速度以获得更亮或更暗的效果。

在大多数情况下，您不需要曝光补偿。但如果您发现自己想要调整曝光，请不要害怕使用它！

光圈优先模式与快门优先模式

光圈优先可控制光圈和 ISO，而相机则负责调整快门速度。如果您需要控制图像中的景深，这是一个很棒的工具。

另一方面，快门优先可让您调整快门速度和 ISO。然后，您的相机会选择相应的光圈以获得正确的曝光。如果您要处理快速移动的主题，此模式特别有用。

比较两者，您会发现光圈优先通常更受欢迎。许多摄影师都欣赏控制背景清晰度和模糊度的能力。

但快门优先也有它的粉丝，尤其是那些拍摄体育或其他高速活动的人。该模式可以精确控制运动，因此您可以捕捉每一个令人兴奋的细节，甚至引入有意的模糊。

然而，当您需要控制景深和运动的整体构图时，您可能会发现光圈优先更有吸引力。在某些情况下，快门优先可能是不可或缺的，但光圈优先通常可以提供更大的创作自由。

光圈优先模式与手动模式

手动模式更进一步，可以完全控制每个相机设置，包括快门速度、光圈和 ISO。这是确保您获得所需的准确曝光结果的有效方法。

然而，这种完全控制是以速度为代价的。手动调整所有这些变量意味着手动模式的使用速度通常较慢。它非常适合您可以非常谨慎地工作的场景，例如风景或工作室设置。

请注意，与手动模式相比，光圈优先提供了一种快速的方法来适应照明条件或拍摄对象移动的变化。当时间至关重要时，相机对快门速度进行的自动调整尤其重要。

在光线快速变化或拍摄对象从阴影移动到阳光并返回的情况下，光圈优先模式可提供捕捉瞬间所需的速度。手动模式虽然在控制方面无与伦比，但在这些动态情况下可能不是最佳选择。

最后，您在光圈优先和手动模式之间的选择可能取决于场景的具体要求以及您作为摄影师的个人喜好。光圈优先提供速度和一定的控制，而手动模式则提供微调图像各个方面的机会。两种模式都有独特的优势和应用，因此了解它们的差异将帮助您选择适合您的创意愿景的工具。

什么时候应该使用光圈优先模式？

首先，如果您是希望更好地了解相机设置的初学者，光圈优先是一个很好的使用模式。因为您的相机会自动选择快门速度，所以您不必担心曝光混乱 - 但同时，您可以尝试不同的光圈并查看图像如何变化。

另外，随着技能的提高，您可以开始使用光圈来有意调整快门速度，并使用曝光补偿功能来改善图像细节。

但光圈优先模式在已经掌握了相机设置的专业人士中也很受欢迎。其一，如果您不需要考虑快门速度但确实关心光圈，则光圈优先会将您的注意力集中在重要的设置上（并让您忘记不太重要的快门速度设置）。例如，如果您在光线良好的情况下拍摄人像照片，光圈优先可让您调整景深而不会分心。

此外，与完全手动模式不同，光圈优先可以帮助您对光线变化做出反应。例如，如果拍摄对象从阴影区域移动到阳光明媚的区域，或者太阳从云层后面露出来，光圈优先将自动调整快门速度以补偿突然爆发的光线。

在某些较慢的摄影类型中，例如风景摄影，这并不是特别有用 - 但如果您拍摄动作，对光线变化做出快速反应至关重要，而光圈优先可以产生巨大的影响。

以下是光圈优先较受欢迎的几种类型：

  • 人像摄影
  • 鸟类摄影
  • 野生动物摄影
  • 微距摄影
  • 街头摄影

当然，对于某种类型来说，不存在单一的最佳相机模式，您总能找到工作方式不同的摄影师 - 但上面的列表是一个很好的起点。

如何使用光圈优先模式：分步

使用光圈优先模式非常简单。

首先，将相机模式转盘设置为“Av”或“A”。

接下来，设置您喜欢的 ISO（通常是相机提供的最低设置）。

第三，根据景深考虑选择光圈。换句话说，如果想要深景深，就选择窄光圈，如果想要浅景深，就选择大光圈。

第四，检查你的快门速度。对于您的拍摄对象来说，速度足够快吗？如果您拍摄运动、飞行中的鸟类、汽车等，并且需要更快的快门速度，请提高 ISO 或扩大光圈。

如果您正在拍摄移动的水、移动的云或其他想要进行艺术模糊的移动主体，请考虑降低 ISO 或缩小光圈以降低快门速度。

接下来，进行试拍并仔细观察结果。如果一切看起来都不错——包括曝光——那么就继续拍摄。

另一方面，如果您的测试图像看起来曝光过度或曝光不足，请调入一些曝光补偿，然后才开始认真拍摄。

处理常见的光圈优先场景

在本节中，我将研究一些光圈优先模式可以发挥作用的常见情况，并分享一些设置建议。

人像摄影

光圈优先模式非常适合人像摄影，因为它可以让您在相机处理曝光时考虑景深。

大多数人像照片都具有浅景深效果，拍摄对象清晰，但背景美丽模糊：

只需选择低 ISO（例如 ISO 100），然后调大光圈即可。 f/2.8 光圈是一个不错的起点，但如果您的镜头提供 f/1.8 或 f/1.4 最大光圈，请不要害怕进一步扩大设置。

街头摄影

如果您在阳光明媚的繁忙城市街道上拍摄，光圈优先模式是您的最佳选择。

选择相对较窄的光圈，例如 f/8，以使大部分场景保持清晰。然后提高 ISO，直到在阴影处设置合理的快门速度（1/250 秒是拍摄的最佳最低速度）。

这样，当您和拍摄对象进出阴影时，您的相机将确保曝光保持平衡！

动作摄影

如果您要拍摄体育运动员或其他快速移动的物体，只需拨入相对较宽的光圈（例如 f/4 或 f/5.6）即可。

选择一个可以提供较快快门速度的 ISO（对于许多动作主题，1/1000 秒是一个很好的起点）。

然后，当太阳移到云层后面时，您的相机将自动调整快门速度以补偿光线的损失，最终您将获得美丽的图像。

微距摄影

光圈优先是拍摄令人惊叹的微距照片的好方法；通过控制光圈，可以创造出美丽的浅景深效果！

靠近并拨入大光圈设置。这使您可以专注于复杂的细节，例如花瓣的纹理或昆虫的眼睛，并且它会在背景中产生令人惊叹的模糊，突出主要拍摄对象。

尝试不同的光圈可以让您看到景深如何变化。不要害怕测试各种设置来实现您想要的效果。

这是一个可以提供令人难以置信的结果的实践过程。无论您是要捕捉蝴蝶精致的翅膀还是树叶的复杂图案，光圈优先都可以灵活地实现这一目标。

野生动物和鸟类摄影

野生动物和鸟类摄影需要精度和速度的平衡。光圈优先模式允许您选择相当宽的光圈，但又不能太宽以致拍摄对象只能部分对焦。

选择合适的光圈是第一步。然后，您可以检查所选的快门速度，并根据需要通过提高或降低 ISO 进行调整。这种方法可以随着拍摄对象的移动进行快速调整。

请记住：野生动物摄影通常涉及不可预测的动作。一只鸟可能会突然飞翔，或者一只动物可能会从阳光飞向阴影。

在这些动态场景中，光圈优先可帮助您保持对拍摄对象的关注，同时仍允许进行调整以捕捉动作。这种控制力和适应性的结合是许多摄影师在野外时选择光圈优先的原因！

光圈优先模式：最后的话

光圈优先是一种功能强大的相机模式，对于专业人士和初学者来说都非常有用。

所以尝试一下光圈优先。练习调整您的设置。我打赌你会喜欢这个结果！

您会在照片中使用光圈优先吗？在下面的评论中分享您的想法！

什么时候会使用光圈优先模式？

如果您希望控制相机曝光设置而不直接进入手动模式，那么光圈优先模式非常有用。如果您想控制光圈但不关心调节特定的快门速度，它也很棒。

光圈优先有什么缺点？

光圈优先不允许您拨入您喜欢的快门速度。如果您想完全控制您的设置，请尝试手动模式。

专业摄影师使用光圈优先吗？

当然是！许多专业人士经常使用光圈优先。

光圈优先是街头摄影的最佳模式吗？

这取决于您的拍摄风格和喜好。当您在可变照明下拍摄拍摄对象时，它当然可以很好地工作！

拍摄美丽的海景照片似乎很困难，但它并不像您想象的那么难 - 一旦您了解一些简单的技巧。

我从事海景摄影多年，在这篇文章中，我分享了我的主要技巧，包括：

  • 获得一致结果的最佳设置
  • 如何为令人惊叹的海景图像选择完美的照明
  • 如何选择正确的地点和潮汐来拍摄精彩照片
  • 多得多！

准备好像专业人士一样拍摄海景照片了吗？然后让我们直接开始，从我的第一个提示开始：

1. 采取适当的安全预防措施

首先要做的事情是：

海景摄影可能很危险。作为一名海景摄影师，随着潮水上涨和海浪越来越近，您将花时间在光滑而尖锐的岩石上徒步旅行。

因此，请始终注意周围环境并不断观察周围发生的事情。我被困在一块岩石上，周围只有一片狂野的大海。我也曾被怪异的海浪完全浸湿，我不止一次差点丢了相机。

另一方面，如果您采取适当的预防措施，您会发现海上冒险的结果是非常值得的！穿有足够牵引力的鞋子，随身携带手机，并随身携带防水袋，以备需要保护相机时使用。并注意潮汐；如果它开始出现，请确保您有明确的退出策略。

最后，与其他摄影师一起拍摄，以便在必要时可以互相帮助。

2. 侦察该地区并跟随潮汐

一旦选定了海景拍摄地点，就开始了考察之旅。考虑可能的前景元素（例如岩石和沙子图案），寻找令人惊叹的背景（例如海蚀柱），并仔细注意水位。

此外，花大量时间研究潮汐。大多数沿海城镇都会有潮汐表或图表（您也可以简单地谷歌“[位置]潮汐表”），我鼓励您仔细研究它。

现在，海景照片没有最佳潮汐。正确的潮汐取决于地点，这就是为什么侦察之旅如此重要。当您确定关键的前景和背景时，您需要注意潮汐 - 然后确保您计划在基本构图元素曝光的时间拍摄您的照片。 （你不想在退潮时侦察，只是在涨潮时带着相机返回，却发现你原本打算拍摄的岩石现在被淹没了！）

请记住，潮汐会影响水的运动和波浪的大小。涨潮通常会在海滩上产生大量波浪运动，但它可能会限制其他区域的水流运动，因此请特别注意，并在条件合适时出发。

哦，一定要记住留意潮水可能上涨的区域。小河道和沟壑看似无害，但在涨潮时却非常危险。退潮时，水可能会退去，但当潮水来临时，这些区域就变得无法穿越。

专业提示：在计划拍摄时与当地摄影师和渔民聊天是个好主意。当地人通常拥有大量从潮汐图上无法获得的知识。

3. 追踪天气

您想要柔和、宁静的海景图像吗？或者暴风雨天空的激烈、戏剧性镜头？在这里，天气变化很大 - 因此提前计划非常重要。

不幸的是，大多数沿海地区的天气非常难以预测。暴风雨来得很快。或者，当您希望看到乌云时，您可能会发现自己对晴朗的天空感到沮丧。

因此，请务必在计划拍摄前几个小时查看天气预报，然后在出发前再次查看天气预报。我还鼓励您在拍摄时经常观察天空。这样，如果发生意外的风暴，您就可以做好准备。

请记住，天气，尤其是风，可能会使拍摄清晰的海景照片变得困难。强风会摇动你的三脚架，让你（和你的相机）沾满海浪——所以一定要带上毛巾，如果天气变得太恶劣，不要害怕放弃。

4. 提前选择地点和照明

沿海地区提供了各种各样的摄影机会，而且很容易让人不知所措——所以我鼓励您提前确定您感兴趣的区域。 （正如我在之前的技巧中讨论的那样，侦察之旅是无价的！）

选择位置后，使用PhotoPills等应用程序确定日出和日落时太阳的位置。这样，您就可以确保您在正确的时间处于正确的位置。

说到太阳：

与所有风景摄影一样，海景摄影的最佳照明类型是黄金时段（日出后和日落前）和蓝色时段（日出前和日落后）。黄金时段是捕捉具有令人惊叹的光影的神奇镜头的好方法，而蓝色时段则保证了空灵的光线，可实现华丽的长时间曝光。

因此，请计划一天中正确的外出时间，并在光线合适前一小时左右就位。这样，您就有足够的时间来设置和确定完美的构图。

还有一条建议：

如果您打算在清晨或深夜拍摄，请购买头灯。在黑暗中攀爬岩石并不好玩，一些额外的照明将有助于确保您的安全。

5. 使用正确的快门速度来模糊（或冻结）水

在海景摄影中，通常有两种选择：

  1. 您可以模糊水以获得神奇的效果
  2. 您可以冻结波浪的运动以增加强度

这两种选择都不比另一种更好。这一切都取决于您的创意愿景。但重要的是要将相机切换到手动模式并有意选择快门速度。

就我个人而言，当我的构图包含水在前景元素上滚动时，我喜欢模糊水。这样，我可以赋予水柔和、丝滑的效果，并创建看起来有些超现实的图像。为了获得我想要的效果，我通常需要 1/30 秒或更慢的快门速度，这在蓝色时段拍摄时很容易实现，但当太阳仍在地平线上方时则很难实现。最好携带一两个中性密度滤光片；这些只是使场景变暗，这样即使在较亮的光线下您也可以使用较长的快门速度。

专业提示：尝试将中性密度滤光片与蓝光小时光结合使用。您确实可以降低快门速度并创造出梦幻般的效果 - 水雾缭绕和云彩斑斓。

请注意，并不总是能够完美预测慢快门速度对水面的影响。不同的水流速度会产生不同类型的长时间曝光模糊，因此我鼓励您尽可能多地进行实验并拍摄大量图像！

如果您面临强烈的波浪作用，您可能希望冻结场景。为了获得最佳效果，您需要以 1/1000 秒或更快的速度拍摄 - 这需要良好的光线或高 ISO 。

6.使用窄光圈保持场景清晰

海景摄影几乎无一例外都是在窄光圈下完成的。

为什么？窄光圈可增加景深，以便您拍摄出前景和背景都清晰对焦的照片。这样，观看者就能够以清晰的细节欣赏整个场景，从最近的沙粒到最远的云：

为了获得最佳效果，您需要使用 f/8 至 f/16 范围内的光圈。比 f/8 更宽的光圈将阻止您捕捉足够的景深，而比 f/16 更窄的光圈会产生导致模糊的衍射。

顺便说一句，要拍出清晰的深景深镜头，不仅仅需要选择窄光圈。您还需要仔细对焦镜头以获得最佳效果。确保将镜头切换到手动对焦，然后选择大约进入场景三分之一的焦点（这里的想法是近似超焦距，这将使景深最大化！）。

7. 拍摄更亲密的海景照片

海洋的广角镜头可能令人叹为观止，但亲密的海景也有其自身的魅力。关注贝壳、卵石或海藻等细节可以揭示更微妙的故事。

微距摄影可能是这里令人兴奋的探索途径。在更高的放大倍率下，海滨自然元素的纹理和颜色可以成为令人着迷的主题。倒影、涟漪，甚至光线在水面上舞动的方式都可以提供无限的创意可能性。

或者，长焦镜头可以帮助您隔离远处的物体，例如船只或灯塔，这样您就可以拍摄被浩瀚大海包围的孤独拍摄对象。

如果您使用浅景深，艺术和梦幻般的图像就触手可及。将光圈扩大到 f/2.8，看看是否可以创作出能引起观众更深层次共鸣的照片！

8. 不要害怕转换成黑白

海景图像的色彩看起来令人惊叹，但它们的黑白效果也同样出色。

因此，我鼓励您以彩色拍摄，但在编辑时，将文件转换为单色。看看你的想法。如果您不喜欢结果，可以随时点击“撤消”按钮！

（ 在 Lightroom 中进行快速黑白转换就像单击按钮一样简单，大多数其他程序也是如此。）

当您外出拍摄时，您还应该尝试以黑白方式“观看”。最好的黑白海景照片往往以丝滑的水为特色——曝光时间越长越好！ – 前景有充足的对比度。

顺便说一句，如果您在单调的日子外出拍摄，看看是否可以创建更简约的构图（即包含大量负空间）。这些图像在彩色时可能看起来不太像，但通过快速的黑白转换和对比度的增强，您最终会得到一批令人惊叹的、甚至永恒的图像。

9. 务必使用三脚架！

每当您外出拍摄海景时，请务必带上三脚架。当您拍摄长时间曝光时，三脚架可以使您的相机保持稳定，它可以帮助您获得必要的景深，并且可以极大地改善您的构图。

是的，三脚架可能很麻烦。但它们绝对值得付出努力，所以如果您还没有坚固的三脚架，那就买一个吧。

我建议使用碳纤维三脚架；这些型号结合了坚固的结构和轻巧的机身。然而，如果您不想花钱购买优质的碳纤维三脚架，铝制三脚架是另一种选择（尽管您需要定期清洁它以防止海浪腐蚀！）。

请注意，即使是最坚固的三脚架在受到风浪的冲击时也可能难以支撑您的相机，因此当天气变得非常恶劣时，您可能需要收拾行李。当您将三脚架放置在沙滩海岸线上时，请注意：当进水时，您的三脚架可能会轻微下沉，导致图像模糊。之后务必检查您的文件，以确保岩石和云看起来清晰。

10.选择正确的前景和背景主题

最好的海景照片具有引人注目的构图，通常具有引人注目的前景元素和美丽的背景。因此，当您外出拍摄时，不要只是放下相机拍摄地平线；而要拍摄地平线。相反，寻找有趣的前景和背景，直到找到令人惊叹的组合。

如果您正在努力寻找好的前景，这里有一些想法：

  • 岩石露头
  • 沙子里的图案
  • 水流流向海洋
  • 波浪动作
  • 令人惊叹的潮汐池
  • 鹅卵石

这是我最喜欢的海景背景：

  • 灯塔
  • 海蚀柱
  • 令人惊叹的日出和日落天空
  • 暴风雨云
  • 船

当然，您不必将自己限制在我的清单上。重要的是你要找到共同吸引观众的前景和背景！

11. 在你的图像中加入野生动物

海景不仅仅是水和天空；还有。它们充满了生命力。在相框中添加当地鸟类或海洋动物可以为您的照片增添新的趣味。

当地的鸟类，如海鸥或鹈鹕，经常潜水捕鱼或乘风滑翔。捕捉他们的动作可以为您的镜头增添动态感。根据您所在的位置，海豚或海豹等海洋动物可能会惊喜地出现，并提供真正独特的拍照机会。

如果您要拍摄远处的野生动物，长焦镜头可能是一个很有价值的工具，但您也可以通过简单地描绘自然环境中的野生动物来获得很好的效果。

总体而言，请考虑野生动物如何与您的海景相得益彰，并确保各种元素协同工作。将野生动物纳入其中需要平衡和深思熟虑，以确保动物能够增强而不是分散您想要捕捉的美丽风景。

12.尝试一些天线

在过去的几年里，无人机摄影席卷了世界。 And while drone shots can get a little repetitive, a drone's view from high above the sea can reveal gorgeous geometric patterns in the features below – the kind that seascape shooters shouldn't miss! Curves of the coastline, the ebb and flow of waves, and boasts coasting across the waves all come to life from an overhead vantage point.

So if you have access to a drone, use it! Fly at different altitudes and angles to uncover unique perspectives. Experiment by including or excluding the sky from the shots.

Also, note that the sea's grandeur and beauty can be accentuated by the right lighting and time of day. Sunsets, in particular, can cast a magical glow over the waters, while harsh midday light can make for interesting high-contrast shots.

Remember, though, to be mindful of the weather conditions. The seaside can be a rough place. Safety should always be your priority; you don't want to lose your drone to a stray gust of wind! Also, different locations have different drone laws, and respecting these regulations is vital to a successful aerial shoot. Always do your research before sending that drone up into the sky!

13. Use intentional camera movement for creative abstracts

Intentional camera movement isn't about randomly shaking your device; rather, it's a creative way to transform an ordinary seascape into something abstract and artistic.

Begin by setting your camera to Manual mode or Shutter Priority, then dial in a slower shutter speed. This allows the sensor to record movements made during the exposure.

Experiment by moving the camera horizontally. You might be surprised how this simple motion can create an abstract effect, adding energy to your ocean shots. Feel the rhythm of the sea and try to translate it into your photography.

Vertical movements offer another avenue for creativity. The result is often an ethereal look that takes your seascapes to a whole new level. It feels more like painting with light rather than capturing a still moment.

Of course, you can only go upward from there! A combination of horizontal and vertical movements can create unexpected results. Intentional camera movement is a playful technique, and you can spend hours discovering new possibilities!

Seascape photography tips: final words

Well, there you have it:

13 tips to take your seascape photos to the next level.

Seascape photography is often exhilarating, magical, and humbling – all at the same time. Just remember: Always stay safe, and do your best to plan out photos in advance.

The post An Essential Guide to Night Portrait Photography appeared first on Digital Photography School . It was authored by Sean McCormack .

Night portraits offer a mystical blend of shadow and artificial light. When done well, the results can be enchanting – even breathtaking.

That said, night portrait photography doesn't come without challenges. Focusing in the darkness can be a struggle, and achieving sharp, well-exposed images can feel impossible. As a result, many portraitists give up before they really get started.

Fortunately, capturing gorgeous portraits in the darkness is possible. And as long as you're equipped with the right techniques, it can be surprisingly simple. I love shooting portraits at night, and in this article, I share my best advice, including:

  • The best settings for beautiful results
  • How to use artificial light and natural light for outstanding effects
  • Any easy way to capture gorgeous nighttime backgrounds
  • Much more!

Ready to become a night portrait master? Then let's dive right in!

Night portrait photography settings

When tackling night portraiture, you'll need to tweak your camera settings to balance the limited lighting with a need for beautiful image quality. Here's the approach I recommend:

The best camera mode for night portraits

Auto mode is easy to use – you can simply set it and forget it – but it's terrible for night portrait photography.

If you use your camera in Auto mode, you'll generally end up with one of two results:

  1. You'll get a blurry, unusable image
  2. Your subject will be heavily flashed and the background will turn black

In my experience, neither of the above outcomes is ideal, which is why it's essential to move away from Auto mode as soon as you can.

What mode should you use instead?

One option is your camera's Night Scene mode, which will fire your flash while also selecting a longer shutter speed . This can net you some nice shots, but it won't give you control over your settings.

Therefore, a better option is either Manual mode or Aperture Priority mode . Both Manual and Aperture Priority let you change your camera settings at will. In Aperture Priority, you select the aperture and the ISO , while your camera selects a shutter speed for a balanced exposure . In Manual mode, you select the aperture, the ISO, and the shutter speed, while your camera selects nothing (in other words, you have total control!).

If you've never tried Aperture Priority, then I'd suggest starting there. You can use it to familiarize yourself with the different exposure settings. Then, as you gain confidence, you can switch over to Manual and see what you think.

The best aperture, shutter speed, and ISO for night portraits

Once you've chosen the perfect camera mode, it's time to pick your main exposure settings: the aperture, the shutter speed, and the ISO.

Note that these three settings together produce the exposure – ie, overall brightness – of the photo. One goal to keep in mind when picking your settings, therefore, is to create an image with plenty of detail in the shadows, highlights, and midtones.

However, the aperture, shutter speed, and ISO also affect other aspects of each image. The aperture adjusts the depth of field of the scene , the shutter speed determines scene sharpness, and the ISO influences the overall image quality.

Therefore, you need to choose each setting carefully . Here are my recommendations:

  • Pick your aperture first based on your depth of field requirements. If you want an artistic shallow depth of field effect , then choose a wide aperture, such as f/2.8. If you want a sharper background, go for a narrower aperture, such as f/8.
  • Next, choose the slowest shutter speed that'll get you consistently sharp shots. If your subject is stationary, you might choose 1/160s. If your subject is moving, you might go for 1/500s or higher.
  • Finally, dial in your camera's native ISO value (generally ISO 100) for the highest-quality photos.

Once you've chosen your ideal settings, frame your subject and check the exposure meter. If your image is underexposed, then you'll need to either increase your ISO or widen your aperture further. Personally, I'm a fan of shallow depth of field portraits, so I don't mind widening the aperture as far as it'll go – but if you're set on a sharp background, then go ahead and boost the ISO until you have a good exposure.

If your image is overexposed, then simply boost the shutter speed until the exposure meter is balanced.

Night portrait photography lighting

Without some form of artificial lighting, you'll struggle to capture detailed images of your portrait subjects. The shots will turn out either wildly underexposed or very blurry, neither of which is ideal.

Note that your artificial lighting need not be a flash. It can be a streetlight, a neon sign, a phone flashlight – anything that lights up your subject and provides a bit of illumination for your camera to use. Of course, the light needs to be accessible; if you plan to use streetlights for your next photoshoot, for instance, make sure there are some nearby and on public land!

That said, I do recommend carrying an off-camera flash for nighttime portraits. This will give you the most flexibility – you can adjust the brightness and the direction – and you can use it to produce beautiful effects.

I'd also recommend buying a light stand, which you can use to mount your flash. (Alternatively, you can bring an assistant, who can hold the flash and aim it as needed.) You might even consider purchasing a modifier , which will soften the light for a more flattering effect.

Tips for breathtaking night portrait photography

If you're looking to get pro-level night portraits – the kind that are moody and powerful and oh-so-compelling all at the same time – then you'll want to rely on a few handy tricks of the trade. In this section, I offer plenty of techniques to get you started.

1. Use a camera or lens with image stabilization

Shooting in low light often means dealing with slower shutter speeds – and when the shutter is slow, even a slight shake of the hand can result in a blurry shot. This is where image stabilization comes to the rescue. It's designed to counteract small movements caused by camera shake as well as the vibrations from pressing the shutter button.

The benefit of image stabilization in night portraiture can't be overstated. It can truly be the difference between a sharp shot and a blurry one, especially if your subject is stationary. Many lenses come with this feature, and manufacturers give it a variety of names, so keep an eye out for terms like “VR,” “IS,” “OIS,” or “OS” when choosing a lens.

Also, if you're considering a new camera, some mirrorless models do offer built-in image stabilization. However, these cameras tend to be quite expensive, so it's always good to keep lens image stabilization in mind.

2. Don't be afraid to use a tripod and flash

If you photograph portraits with a flash, the subject will turn out nice and bright – but the background will be unaffected (and will therefore remain dark).

So you have three options:

  1. You can embrace the black-background effect.
  2. You can boost your ISO until the background looks decently bright.
  3. You can mount your camera on a tripod, then capture a long exposure with a burst from your flash.

A black background can look nice, especially if you're after a moodier image (see the example below). And a high ISO will get you a good exposure (at the cost of reduced image quality).

But the long-exposure technique can produce great images, too, so I recommend you learn how it works.

First, make sure you have a sturdy tripod. I'd also encourage you to grab a remote release, which will let you trigger your camera without pressing the shutter button.

Set up your image, then choose your exposure settings based on the background, not the subject. To prevent your subject from turning too bright, dial in a shutter speed that'll keep the background subtly underexposed. Note that your shutter speed should be reasonably long (generally 1/30s or below) in order to bring out detail in the background areas.

Finally, fire the shutter and the flash. The idea is that the flash will freeze your subject, while the lengthy shutter speed will give the camera enough time to record light from the background. You'll get a beautiful result, one with a detailed (if slightly underexposed) background:

If your first shots don't turn out great, that's okay! Nailing flash brightness can take some tweaking. If your subject is too bright but you like the background exposure, then try dropping the flash brightness or taking a few steps back from your subject. Alternatively, if your subject is too dark, increase the flash brightness or get closer to the subject.

3. Pay attention to the background

When doing night portrait photography, it's easy to forget about the background . After all, it's often too dark to see, plus your subject is what's really important, right?

Not quite.

First of all, even in situations where you let the background fade to black, the final image will likely include some background elements, such as car lights, street lights, or lit-up signs.

And if you use the technique I shared in the previous tip, then the background will be clearly visible in the final photo, even if it's tough to see through your camera viewfinder.

In truth, the background is an essential part of every portrait photo, whether you shoot at night or in bright daylight. A good background emphasizes and complements the main subject, while a bad background distracts the viewer and prevents them from fully appreciating the subject.

So if you want great shots, you've got to get the background right.

When preparing for a photoshoot, I'd recommend scouting around for potential backdrops. Search for lots of streetlights – which look stunning when combined with a wide aperture, as I discuss below – as well as simple walls that'll help your subject stand out.

And then, when you're out shooting, always pay careful attention to the area behind your subject. Make sure that it doesn't distract the viewer. And don't be afraid to test out different backgrounds by changing your camera angle!

4. Seek out spots of light for exceptional backgrounds

My previous night portraits tip was all about enhancing the background. This tip continues in the same vein – but with a focus on one of the most effective ways to create stunning backdrops that complement your subject.

You see, the night is filled with pockets of light that can bring magic to your portraits. Neon signs glowing in a distant alley, streetlights shimmering on a rain-soaked pavement, or festive decorations twinkling in a park – all these sources of artificial light can look amazing, especially when used to produce gorgeous bokeh.

Here's what you do: Position your subject so that pinpricks of light are visible in the background, and use a wide aperture to create a shallow depth of field effect. Focus on your subject, then watch as those distant points of light turn into beautiful, soft orbs.

(Pro tip: Focusing can be more challenging at night, so don't hesitate to use manual focus or a single-point AF mode to nail the shot.)

Work with angles and distances to find that perfect composition. Moving closer to your subject will generally increase the presence of the bokeh, while moving away from your subject will minimize it. Give yourself some room to experiment, too. The most obvious shot isn't always the best!

5. Start out with continuous lighting

I know I've talked a lot about using flash for beautiful night photos, but while flash is very versatile, portable, and powerful, it can be a difficult light source for beginners to handle. You can't see the effect of the flash until after an image is taken, which means that you'll spend a lot of time guessing, checking, and adjusting your lights. Plus, getting the exposure right when using flash can be a struggle; you'll often need to spend long minutes shifting the flash brightness up and down until you get a result you like.

Fortunately, there is another option: Continuous lights . These will constantly light your subject and therefore allow you to monitor their effects in real-time.

You can grab portable continuous lights for a reasonable price, and while they aren't as powerful as flash, they work great for nighttime portraits. Plus, continuous lights often offer color temperature adjustments, which let you match the light color to surrounding light sources for a more natural effect.

Now, for the best results, you'll probably need to boost your ISO and/or widen your aperture. I'd suggest setting your exposure based on the background, then ask your subject to step into the frame and make adjustments as required.

For the image below, I used an LED panel. It produced warm, soft light that looked amazing :

Pro tip: If your continuous lights don't feature a brightness control, simply move the lights closer or farther from your subject!

6. Try shooting in black and white

The colors of the night can indeed look stunning, but have you considered the emotive power of black and white? Stripping away color brings out the textures, contrasts, and shadows in a way that can create a moodier and even grittier effect.

High ISO settings – which are sometimes necessary for night portrait photography – often lead to noisy images. While this can be a drawback when shooting in color, noise tends to look much better in monochrome. It can add an appealing grain and texture, reminiscent of traditional film photography.

Bottom line: Exploring contrasts and shadows with a black-and-white palette can lead to dramatic and visually engaging results.

Also, I highly recommend working in RAW. That way, you'll have the flexibility to convert your image to black and white during post-processing, and you'll have plenty of latitude when testing out various monochrome effects so you can find the look that best suits your creative vision.

7. Consider styling your subject

When you're just starting out as a night portrait photographer, you'll likely photograph your subjects as they are.

However, as you become more experienced, you may want to get someone to do their hair and makeup. You might even purchase stylish clothes for your subjects to make the shots look even better.

Even if you just use friends as models, it's a good idea to ensure they look professional – so guide them in picking out clothing from their wardrobe.

Of course, you'll want to keep in mind the purpose of your night portraits. If you're shooting fine-art images, then it's okay to push drama and unorthodox clothing choices. However, if your goal is to capture nice portraits for your subject to hang on their wall, you may want to tone down the styling. Make sense?

8. Add color grading to your images

Color grading is an artistic touch that can make your night portraits truly stand out. It refers to the deliberate process of adding hues to your images during post-processing in order to create a specific mood or style. Night images, in particular, look fantastic with color grading applied.

I encourage you to spend time experimenting with different colors in your favorite post-processing program. The most popular editors for color grading generally offer color wheels, so you can select your preferred hues with precision.

One classic combination that rarely fails is adding blue into the shadows and orange into the highlights; it creates a warm and cool contrast that can be visually stunning. Don't hesitate to try out different color combinations, though. The experimentation phase can lead to beautiful and unexpected results.

9. Try adding props

Props can add depth, context, and a spark of creativity to your night portraits. Selecting the right props is crucial, however, especially when working in low light.

Go with items that fit that moody nighttime vibe. Reflective objects or those that generate their own light can produce fascinating effects. Large glasses are especially popular in night portrait circles and can catch ambient light in intriguing ways.

Fairy lights are another fantastic option; you can have your subject hold them or drape them around your subject to add a soft glow to the image.

But make sure to balance your props with the overall theme and mood of the photograph. Avoid props that might feel out of place, like a sunflower, and focus on those that enhance the night ambiance. With the right choice of props and a bit of creativity, you can transform an ordinary night portrait into something truly memorable.

10. Use reflective surfaces

Reflective surfaces have a unique way of enhancing night portraits. They provide intrigue and add another layer of creativity to your shots. If you can find and include some nice reflective elements in your composition, you can easily transform a good photograph into a great one.

You'll likely come across plenty of reflective surfaces photographing in urban areas. Windows of cars, shiny metallic railings, and even puddles of water on the street can work great. These reflections can feature neon signs or other colorful lights and produce mesmerizing effects in your night portraits.

Positioning your subject and your camera to maximize these reflections is essential. Experiment with different angles and surfaces; see if you can find a look that really complements the subject. Sometimes, a subtle reflection can add just the right touch of sophistication, but other times, a bold, mirrored image can make a powerful statement.

Also, the more creative you can get with your reflections, the better! Keep an eye out for those unexpected reflections that might showcase the glimmer of a streetlamp or the sparkle of traffic lights. And if you're not sure whether an idea might work, test it!

11. Capture beautiful environmental portraits

Close-up portraits are undoubtedly striking. But have you thought about environmental portraits? A single subject surrounded by the weight of darkness, illuminated by gentle light, can be breathtaking . In such a case, the extra space around the subject provides context, tells a story, and adds an extra layer of meaning to your image.

A wide-angle lens or even taking a few steps back can be all it takes to capture a more encompassing frame. Finding an area without a distracting background is key. Look for spaces that allow your subject to stand out, with minimal interference from unwanted elements.

Pro tip: Incorporating negative space in your composition can lead to a minimalistic yet powerful image. Play around with the environment, and don't be afraid to include background elements that enhance the subject or improve the story. The night offers a dramatic and mysterious backdrop; it's up to you to harness it in your photography.

Night portrait photography: final words

Night portraits might not be easy, but they are within your reach. With practice, patience, and the application of the techniques I've explored, you'll find yourself capturing creative images that resonate with viewers. It's all about stepping out of your comfort zone, experimenting with what the night has to offer, and letting your creativity flow.

So set up a photoshoot. Scout out locations. And have plenty of fun!

是否曾经看着一个简单的水果盘，想知道它是否可以有更多的东西？嗯，可以！静物摄影就是将普通物体转化为视觉艺术，它具有一系列强大的优势：

  1. 它非常容易获得（您可以在自己家里完成！）
  2. 它不需要超昂贵的装备
  3. 这并不像看起来那么难

多年来我一直在拍摄静物图像，在这篇文章中，我提供了改进照片所需的一切。我涵盖了所有关键元素，包括灯光、构图和编辑——这样，无论您的经验水平如何，您都可以准备好拍摄一些自己的令人惊叹的静物照片。

让我们开始吧。

什么是静物摄影？

静物摄影是一种涉及捕捉无生命物体的艺术形式。这可以包括从一碗水果到精心布置的古董工具的任何东西。

静物摄影的吸引力在于它的易用性和巨大的创造力潜力。通过完全控制从照明到构图的所有元素，您可以将普通的物体变成非凡的东西。

用艺术的眼光看待日常事物是静物摄影的精髓。这是关于在平凡和平凡中寻找美。无论您是专业摄影师还是刚刚起步，静物摄影都会邀请您重新审视世界，这是探索创造力的绝佳方式！

静物摄影必备装备

您不需要花一大笔钱就可以开始静物摄影。入门级无反光镜相机或数码单反相机就可以很好地工作。与简单的傻瓜相机型号相比，这些相机类型提供了更多的控制和灵活性。与近焦镜头配合使用，它们可以让您捕捉拍摄对象的清晰图像，您可以对其进行编辑、打印并挂在墙上。

三脚架是另一个重要物品，虽然并非每个静物摄影师都专门使用三脚架，但它是一个很好的设备。即使是轻微的相机移动也会改变焦点和构图，因此三脚架将有助于简化您的工作流程。更重要的是，它可以让您的相机保持稳定，这对于在弱光条件下获得清晰锐利的图像至关重要。

其他有用的配件包括用于减少阴影的反射器和用于处理过于刺眼的照明的扩散器。

也就是说，您无需为装备疯狂；关键是要明白高质量的图像不一定来自昂贵的设备。使用正确的基本工具，美丽的静物图像完全触手可及。

静物摄影的主要设置

手动模式是静物摄影的起点。在此模式下工作可以让您对图像进行最终控制，从而可以微调光圈、ISO 和快门速度。通过控制这些设置，您的创造力才能真正闪耀。

f/8 等窄光圈是静物摄影的标准选择。它可以使主题保持清晰，为您提供清晰的细节，使您的静物图像脱颖而出。至于 ISO：保持较低以保持最佳图像质量。只要您使用三脚架，快门速度就不那么重要了；您可以减慢速度而不会造成模糊。

了解这些设置对于获得专业外观的照片至关重要。虽然调节光圈、ISO 和快门速度一开始可能看起来很技术性，但您会发现它很快就会成为第二天性！

静物摄影的基本照明

光线是静物摄影的重要组成部分，许多静物都有美丽的灯光布置（通常会产生喜怒无常的绘画效果）。

但重要的是要认识到，您不需要华丽的灯光来创造令人惊叹的静物画。当您开始时，我建议使用您拥有的任何灯光，例如：

  • 来自窗户的间接光
  • 一盏灯
  • 手电筒
  • 蜡烛

不要只是创建您的设置，尝试一下，然后就到此为止。相反，尝试不同的灯光效果！用窗帘遮挡一些窗户光，然后取下窗帘让光线射入。用手电筒照射主要拍摄对象，然后尝试第二次拍摄，将手电筒放在侧面，将拍摄对象笼罩在阴影中。 Make sense?

请注意，如果您使用灯、手电筒或蜡烛，则肯定需要三脚架；室内照明无法让您获得足够快的快门速度来进行手持拍摄。 （这可能是一个相对便宜的型号；只要将其放置在坚固的表面上，它应该能够保持相机稳定。）当您准备拍摄时，只需将相机安装到三脚架上，启动两个-第二次自拍，并开始拍照。

静物摄影构图

对于初学者来说，学习构图静物照片通常是一件困难的事。这是可以理解的，因为静物构图会带来很多问题，例如：我应该将所有物品放在哪里？它们应该重叠吗？它们应该靠近背景吗？我应该使用什么拍摄角度？

幸运的是，静物构图并不像看起来那么难。我有两个主要建议，它们将带您走得更远：

首先，如果您以前没有遇到过它们，请阅读三分法则和赔率法则。这些将为美丽的静物拍摄提供绝佳的构图起点，而且它们非常易于使用。

其次，不断移动你的物品。

后一个建议可能看起来有点愚蠢，但我保证：如果你足够地重新排列你的对象，你最终会找到一个看起来很棒的排列。不要仅仅满足于您尝试的第一个作品 - 相反，测试一个安排，然后批判性地评估它。确定你喜欢什么、不喜欢什么，然后做出调整。

当您创建不同的作品时，需要注意以下几点：

  • 间隙过于空旷（您通常希望保持整个排列平衡！）
  • 繁忙区域（您不想让观看者因太多活动而感到困惑）
  • 物体之间的移动（旨在引导眼睛从一个物体到下一个物体）

请记住：微小的调整可能会产生巨大的差异。因此，如果安排看起来不完美，请进行一些更改。您很快就会找到更好的设置！

改善静物照片的提示和技巧

现在您已经熟悉了基础知识，让我们深入了解静物摄影的一些更高层次的方面，包括主题选择、不同的照明方向等等！

1. 欣赏伟大静物摄影师的作品

在线研究伟大静物摄影师的作品是一种很有价值的实践。通过观察他们的照片，您可以了解排列元素的不同方式，甚至可以找到新主题的灵感。

但不要只局限于摄影；也看看绘画的世界。像塞尚这样的大师提供了关于构图、平衡和色彩运用的宝贵课程。这些画家布置物体、使用光线和选择颜色的方式可以转化为您摄影的独特见解。画家的构图眼光可以为您的创造力打开新的大门。

向他人学习可能是一个令人兴奋且富有启发性的过程。虽然发展你独特的风格很重要，但你从观察大师那里学到的技巧和想法可以提高你的技能。

2. 尝试侧光

侧光是静物摄影中的一个强大工具。通过确保光源从侧面而不是正面或背面照射到拍摄对象，您可以添加阴影来改善三维感。光影的发挥给图像带来了深度和戏剧性，让普通的物体显得非凡。

45 度角通常是侧光的绝佳起点。它提供了光与影的平衡混合，产生视觉上吸引人的效果。不要害怕尝试不同的角度和光源；实验是找到最适合您的特定设置的关键。

请注意，光线角度可以极大地改变照片的氛围和外观。通过接受实验并了解侧光的工作原理，您可以为静物摄影工具箱添加一个重要的工具。这是朝着创建更具吸引力、更引人注目的图像迈出的一步。

底线：无论您使用窗户的自然光还是人造光源，侧光都可以成为您拍摄令人惊叹的静物照片的首选。

3. 选择您感兴趣的项目

静物摄影初学者常常很难选择一个主题并开始拍摄。但事实上，没有“最好”的静物题材，所以没有必要强调！理想的主题就是您感兴趣的项目，它们可以来自任何地方，包括：

  • 你家周围
  • 跳蚤市场和旧货店
  • 地产销售
  • 杂货店
  • 花店

当然，“静物”这个词通常会让人联想到花瓶、烛台上的梨、旧纸和小提琴。通过获取和排列这些“经典”物品，您当然可以拍摄出美丽的静物照片。

但如果你不感兴趣，你就不需要花时间去追求这些图像。相反，问问自己：什么对我来说有意义？我喜欢什么对象？我想用静物来讲述一个故事吗？

4. 有一个主题

还在为选择合适的静物摄影主题而苦苦挣扎吗？然后我强烈建议围绕一个主题进行工作。

主题是静物摄影的一个重要方面，可以增加图像的深度和连贯性。它们可以帮助您超越随机选择的对象，并促使您思考您想要传达的情绪和含义。无论是颜色、季节还是概念，统一的主题都可以激发创造力。

例如，如果您选择蓝色主题，您可能会收集蓝色玻璃器皿、蓝色围巾或蓝莓等物品。一致的调色板不仅可以创造视觉和谐，还可以让您探索特定颜色系列中的各种纹理和形状。

主题也有助于讲故事。专注于季节性主题（例如秋天）的布置可以唤起温暖、变化或怀旧的感觉。从叶子到南瓜，选择与所选主题产生共鸣的物体有助于创造视觉上引人入胜的故事，与观众对话。

5. 仔细选择背景

背景可以成就——也可以毁掉——你的静物画。如果你想要好的结果，你必须非常谨慎地选择你的背景。

具体来说，不要选择含有分散注意力的元素的背景。避免使用引人注目的颜色，如果您使用布料，请确保先熨烫它（没有什么比起皱的背景更分散注意力了！）。

相反，保持简单。织物、纸板和现有的墙壁通常效果很好，只要它们相对简单。目标是强调静物主题（以便观众确切地知道该看哪里）。

虽然我通常主张在开始时使用窄光圈和深景深，但随着时间的推移，您可能会想要尝试尝试焦点和景深。您可以创建浅景深效果- 保持正面元素清晰，背景模糊 - 以获得更具艺术感的镜头。如果您喜欢背景但发现它有点太显眼，那么这个技巧也可以派上用场。

6.尝试光绘创意静物拍摄

光绘是一种令人兴奋的技术，可以让你用光“绘画”。它包括将相机设置为较长的​​快门速度，通常在 10 到 30 秒的范围内，然后在曝光期间在拍摄对象周围移动手电筒或蜡烛。结果可能令人着迷。

光绘的一大优点是它使您能够更好地控制灯光，而无需投资昂贵的闪光灯和柔光箱。您可以创建独特的效果并准确地在您想要的位置突出显示。您所需要的只是一个黑暗的房间和一个光源，例如手电筒、蜡烛，甚至是荧光棒。

尝试不同的光源、运动和曝光时间。您很快就会发现一个充满创意可能性的全新世界。光绘可以为您的照片增添深度、个性和风格，使其成为静物摄影工具箱中的一项宝贵技术。

7.考虑使用人工照明

一旦您掌握了使用窗户或蜡烛等自然光源的基本静物照明，您可能希望探索人工照明以进行更多控制。影室闪光灯、热靴灯或连续 LED 是常见的选择，每种都有其优点。

对于刚刚起步的人来说，热靴灯可能是一个经济实惠的选择。它们便携且易于使用，但仍能提供出色的效果。另一方面，闪光灯功能更强大，并且包含造型灯，因此您可以提前看到灯光效果。

无论您选择什么，柔光箱都是必不可少的。裸露的闪光灯会产生刺眼且不美观的光线。柔光箱可以漫射光线，使其更加柔和、更加赏心悦目。它们有各种尺寸和形状，让您可以微调灯光效果以适应您的视觉。

人工照明一开始可能看起来令人生畏，但通过练习，您可以使用它来拍摄令人惊叹的静物照片。从产生特定效果到完全控制光的强度和方向，人工照明开辟了创造力的新领域。这不仅是对设备的投资，也是对扩展您的艺术能力的投资。

8.从不同角度拍摄

您选择的拍摄角度可以极大地改变静物照片的外观和感觉。虽然通常从标准的正面构图开始，但尝试不同的角度可以为您的作品集增添丰富性和多样性。

向右或向左移动，从上方或下方拍摄——这些选择为熟悉的主题提供了新的视角。即使相机高度的微小调整也会改变拍摄设置的方式。较高的角度可以放大深度，使物体显得更加分散，而较低的角度可以给人更大的亲密感或宏伟感。

实验是这里的关键。没有严格的规则，因此请随意探索各种角度，直到找到与您的主题和主题产生共鸣的内容。尝试从正上方拍摄一碗水果以强调形状和图案，或从下方拍摄一瓶鲜花以赋予其高耸、雄伟的外观。角度的创造力就在你的手中。

9. 确保花时间编辑静物摄影

后期处理可以对您的静物照片产生巨大的影响，因此我强烈建议您花时间在 Lightroom、Photoshop、Capture One 或其他程序中编辑图像。

从基本调整开始，例如白平衡、曝光、对比度和饱和度。然后，当您变得更有经验时，可以尝试更高级的选项。

1.使用正确的装备

黑白风景摄影可能看起来并不特定于设备，而且在很多方面也并非如此，但某些设备可以增强您的体验和图像质量。

首先，您选择的相机很重要。全画幅型号通常可提供卓越的图像质量，但 APS-C 或微型三分之四型号也可以很棒。如果您要徒步前往不同的地点，更紧凑的无反光镜相机可能会更合适。它更轻， 电子取景器可以让您以黑白方式“查看”，从而提供最终结果的预览。

请注意，大多数适用于标准风景摄影的相机也适用于黑白图像，因此如果您已经拍摄了彩色风景，则可能不需要购买另一台相机！

您对镜头的选择同样重要。您需要涵盖一系列焦距的风景摄影镜头，例如用于一览风景的广角镜头和用于捕捉更紧密细节的长焦镜头。 坚固的风景三脚架是另一个重要的设备，尤其是在长时间曝光或在低光照条件下拍摄时，稳定性是关键。

最后，投资一个好的中性密度滤光片（参见提示＃8！）也可以派上用场。它可以让您控制进入镜头的光量，从而提供对曝光时间的创造性控制。

通过组合这些装备，您将能够使用帮助您实现愿景的工具制作美丽的黑白风景图像。请记住，这不是拥有最昂贵的设备，而是了解如何充分利用您所拥有的设备的潜力。

2. 选择完美的黑白风景设置

When you're getting ready to take a black and white landscape shot, adjusting your camera settings is key.您要做的第一件事是将相机切换到手动模式。它使您可以完全控制图像的各个方面。不用担心;这比听起来容易！

窄光圈（例如 f/8 或更大）可确保从前景到背景的所有内容都保持清晰。如果您想捕捉场景中的所有细节，这一点至关重要。

保持ISO尽可能低也至关重要。较高的 ISO 级别可能会导致图像出现噪点。使用低 ISO 时，您的照片将保留大量细节并显得清晰。

快门速度是另一个需要考虑的重要设置。这可能会根据您想要达到的效果而有所不同。如果您希望创建超长曝光效果（例如河流或瀑布中的丝滑水效果），您可能需要添加中性密度滤镜。该滤镜可让您延长快门速度，而不会过度曝光图像。

手动对焦可能听起来很吓人，但它可以提供更高的精度。自动对焦可能并不总是能准确地选择您想要清晰的位置。通过自行设置焦点（通常在超焦距处，大约进入场景的三分之一处），您可以确保整个镜头清晰。

最后，不要害怕尝试。尝试不同的设置，看看什么最适合您的特定场景。每个景观都是独一无二的，你练习得越多，这些设置就会变得越直观。

3. 适应天气

天气在黑白风景摄影中起着至关重要的作用。与阳光可能提供金色色调的彩色摄影不同，黑白摄影更多的是关于对比度、纹理和形式。

例如，云可以是摄影师最好的朋友。天空中旋转的纹理云可以为风景提供戏剧性的背景。它们提供了自然的对比度，增强了场景的丰富度。

另一方面，晴朗的天空和纯白的天空提供了不同的机会。这些条件更适合包含大量负空间的镜头。晴朗的天空在彩色摄影中可能看起来空虚而暗淡，但在黑白摄影中，它可以创造出强大而简约的图像。阴天可以提供柔和均匀的光线，减少刺眼的阴影，给您带来不同的美感。

但你怎么知道天气会怎样呢？规划是关键。利用天气跟踪应用程序或网站为摄影师提供量身定制的天气预报。这些信息可以帮助您决定最佳的拍摄时间和地点，与您想要营造的情绪或氛围保持一致。

不要害怕尝试不同的天气条件；雨、雾和暴风雨可以为你的黑白风景增添意想不到的魔力。

4. 确保你理解构图

在彩色拍摄时，您可以依靠明亮的绿色、令人惊叹的黄色和闷烧的红色来创造戏剧性和趣味性。事实上，要拍摄出好的彩色风景照片，您通常需要找到一个戏剧性的场景并在美丽的光线下进行拍摄。 （这就是为什么这么多彩色风景照片是在黄金时段或日落后拍摄的。）

但黑白风景摄影非常非常不同。没有色彩，你就不能依赖纯色和光；你必须通过创作强有力的作品来吸引观众。是的，光线很重要，但构图也很重要。除非您能够真正掌握这项技术技能，否则您将很难制作出引人注目的图像。

换句话说，你需要学会寻找摄影构图的组成部分，而不是仅仅追逐强光：引导线、形状、图案、色调对比和纹理。当您接近某个场景时，请尝试忽略有趣的颜色。尽你所能以黑白方式查看，以便快速识别引人注目的几何图形、令人印象深刻的纹理等。

例如，这张照片在黑白效果上效果很好，因为双瀑布和深色岩石之间的色调对比，更不用说平衡的几何形状（全黑背景上的两个双矩形光）：

然而，普通观众（或普通彩色摄影师）第一眼可能不会注意到这些功能。相反，他们会关注游泳池的色调或框架外丰富的绿叶。在您学会以黑白方式观察之前，您可能也会这样做！

5.研究著名黑白风景摄影师的作品

我们自然不会看到黑白分明的世界。因此，学习单色工作需要一些练习。这几乎就像学习一门新语言一样；你必须花时间真正认识什么在黑白照片中有效，什么无效（这通常与彩色风景中的有效）。

现在，您可以通过大量的试验和错误找出如何制作出色的黑白风景，但为什么要重新发明轮子呢？相反，通过观看大师的作品来加深您对黑白风景图像的理解——这些大师已经花了几十年的时间来完善他们的构图、灯光、布景和技术。

我建议从安塞尔·亚当斯和爱德华·韦斯顿开始，他们主要以黑白拍摄，他们的作品与当代风景美学密切相关。您还可以看看 Harry Callahan（如果您对更私密的风景照片感兴趣）以及 Wynn Bullock（他拍摄了精美大气的照片）。

另外，看看现代摄影师在Instagram和500px上做什么。需要搜索的一些名字包括 Cole Thompson、Rob Dweck、Arnaud Bertrande、Thibault Roland、Joel Tjintjelaar 和 Nathan Wirth。

当您观看黑白风景摄影师的作品时，问问自己：是什么让他们的黑白风景照片如此强大？他们使用什么光？他们采用什么摄影技术（例如， 长时间曝光）？他们如何进行构图？

这些答案将教会您很多有关黑白摄影的知识，并将帮助您了解哪些元素和场景真正适合单色处理。

6.寻找色调对比和纹理

色调对比度描述了图像不同部分之间的亮度变化。以下面的照片为例；码头很暗，天空却亮得多。这就是色调对比。黑白效果看起来棒极了。

另一种选择——低色调对比度场景，整个镜头都被中间色调覆盖——往往看起来非常糊状和平坦。音调不会分离，关键元素相互淡化，构图失去影响力。虽然彩色摄影师可能会追求没有色调对比的场景，但他们可以依靠颜色的变化来区分关键元素。然而，在黑白中，这不是一个选择，一切都取决于色调。

纹理（以及纹理之间的对比度）看起来也很棒。如果您考虑一下黑白风景照片中经常出现的元素 - 悬崖、岩石、草地、树木、山脉和海洋，以及码头、防波堤和旧谷仓等人造物体 - 您会发现它们都有独特的纹理。有些具有粗糙、沉重的表面，而另一些则非常光滑。

在下面的照片中，拱门、远处的悬崖和前景中的岩石都具有浓郁的纹理。大海和天空都平滑了很多。岩石的粗糙与海天的平滑形成了强烈的对比。由于这种纹理对比，照片更具冲击力！

7. 以单色模式拍摄

您是否知道您的数码相机可以帮助您以黑白方式观看？

It's true.您所要做的就是将其设置为单色模式。 Your camera's rear LCD will show you a black and white Live View feed – and if your camera includes an electronic viewfinder , that'll turn black and white, too (you can literally look at the world in black and white – how cool is that?).

As you can imagine, constantly looking at the world through a black and white LCD or viewfinder is the perfect way to see how tones are rendered in monochrome. This makes it easier to imagine how scenes will turn out in black and white if you're not shooting in monochrome mode (or if you don't have your camera to your eye).

Personally, I think that black and white electronic viewfinders are an absolute game-changer. If you're serious about B&W landscape photography, it's probably worth switching to a mirrorless camera for that feature alone! After all, it's far easier to compose in black and white when you can see how tonal contrast, texture, lines, shapes, patterns, and light will affect the landscape.

One note, though: Don't forget to set your camera to RAW . RAW files contain all the information captured by your camera's sensor – so if you decide you don't like the image in black and white, you can always convert it to color. If you don't shoot in RAW, however, you'll lose the ability to switch back and forth between color and black and white, and images shot in Monochrome mode will be stuck in monochrome forever.

8. Learn to use neutral density filters

Neutral density filters are a B&W landscape photographer's secret weapon. Grab one (or more) of these accessories, and you'll be able to capture jaw-dropping images beyond your wildest dreams.

(Am I exaggerating? Honestly, I don't think so. Neutral density filters are a huge deal.)

But what makes ND filters so special?

ND filters are basically dark pieces of glass that go in front of your lens and prevent light from hitting your camera sensor. In other words, ND filters block out the light , which lets you lengthen your shutter speed while retaining a balanced exposure.

You see, as a landscape photographer without an ND filter, you'll often be using a shutter speed between 1/2s and 1/125s (assuming you're shooting with a relatively narrow aperture of f/13 or so, which is generally a good idea).

At times, you may want to lengthen your shutter speed for creative effect – so that you can blur water, stretch clouds, and create a beautiful ethereal look in your photos. But in most situations, dropping the shutter speed beyond 1/2s or so just can't be done. The light is too strong; if you try it, you'll end up with an overexposed image.

Unless you have an item that can block out the light – such as a neutral density filter! The ND filter will keep your camera from overexposing the scene even when you're dealing with lots of light. That way, you can push out your shutter speed to 5s, 10s, and more, and you can get the stretchy clouds and blurry water that you're after.

Check out the photos below. The first was taken at dusk with a shutter speed of 1/5s. This exposure time was slow enough to introduce some blur into the water (look at the foreground wave), but it wasn't slow enough to really flatten out the water while making the clouds turn into interesting streaks.

But I added a neutral density filter and made the next photo using a shutter speed of 180 seconds. That way, the water turned out completely blurred and the clouds moved across the sky for a streaking effect:

Bottom line:

Neutral density filters are amazing . They give you control over your shutter speed, which you can then use to enhance your black and white landscapes.

9. Don't just take photos like everyone else

Black and white landscape photographer Cole Thompson has an interesting idea. He practices what he calls “photographic abstinence,” where he doesn't look at the work of other photographers before heading to a new location. The idea is that it enables him to see the landscape through his own eyes without being influenced by other people's photos of the same elements.

I've never taken this idea to its extreme. I believe it's important to research an area before you go; that way, you can find its most photogenic parts and avoid boring areas. But this does lead to a problem: The most powerful images you see tend to stick in your mind. The natural tendency is to want to create similar images – so if you spend time researching locations, you'll often end up capturing photos that look like everybody else's.

I encourage you to push back against this tendency! Recognize that certain subjects are photographed in particular ways. Use that knowledge to capture images that are different – images that are truly you .

Let me give you an example. A few years ago, I visited the Playa de las Catedrales (Cathedral Beach) in northern Spain. Search for it on Google or 500px, and most photos will look something like this, showing the cathedral-like arches for which the beach is named:

Anybody who visits the beach will naturally want to take photos of the arches. They're the reason the spot is famous, after all. But if you only focus on the arches, you'll miss other (equally compelling!) possibilities.

So after traveling to Cathedral Beach and getting my rock arch photos, I really started looking . I saw some rocks in the sea that made an interesting minimalistic composition, and I captured the following photo:

It doesn't feature famous arches. But the shot feels more personal and was more satisfying to take.

10. Try to simplify your compositions

As I mentioned above, black and white photos can get kind of mushy . The files don't include any color information, which means that images can become pretty confusing. Various subjects blend into one another, and the viewer may struggle to understand the scene.

Now, one way to deal with this tendency is to include plenty of tonal contrast. It's a good technique, and I highly recommend it. But if you want to really elevate your B&W photos, you should also aim to cut down on extraneous elements in your compositions. That way, the viewer will know exactly where to focus – and they'll be able to instantly interpret the shot.

So before capturing a new image, ask yourself: Does the frame include any elements that might distract the viewer? Is the viewer able to clearly identify the main subject? Make sure that every part of the scene contributes to the composition.

If you come upon a scene that seems a bit cluttered, don't walk away. Instead, take steps to simplify . Get in closer, use a longer lens, or adjust your angle so that you highlight certain objects and block out others. Make sense?

11. Don't forget about the light

Throughout this article, I've emphasized the importance of composition in black and white landscape photography. And it's true: Composition makes a huge difference.

But make sure you don't fixate so heavily on composition that you forget about other key photographic elements – such as lighting.

Color landscape photographers love shooting during the golden hours, and this soft-yet-direct light also looks great in black and white. The low sun will create long shadows, which you can use as powerful composition elements (eg, leading lines ).

But as a black and white shooter, you can head out at other times and capture equally compelling images. For instance, overcast days produce soft, intimate light that reveals detail in forest and mountain scenes. And even harsh midday sun – which is hated by most color landscape photographers – can make for interesting black and white shots. The trick is to use the contrasty light to your advantage; let it create shadow geometry, then incorporate the shadows into your compositions.

Blue hour is another great time to shoot black and white landscapes. The light is wonderfully soft, and if you can find a moving subject (eg, ocean waves), you'll be able to capture ethereal long exposures that look outstanding .

12. Capture intimate landscape shots

Landscape photography doesn't always mean capturing grand, sweeping vistas. Sometimes, the beauty lies in the details, textures, or geometry found within the scene. These intimate landscape shots can tell a different, more personal story.

Switching from a wide-angle lens to a telephoto lens can transform your perspective. It allows you to zoom in on specific elements, such as a lone tree, a winding path, or the intricate pattern of leaves and rocks. The compression effect of a telephoto lens can also create a unique visual relationship between the foreground and background.

Intimate shots are all about observation and imagination. Look for textures, shapes, and patterns that draw your eye. Experiment with different angles and framing to find the perfect landscape composition . Sometimes, the most compelling images come from the most ordinary subjects, like delicate lines in the sand or the graceful curve of a branch.

Don't be afraid to get close and personal with nature. Part of the beauty of black and white photography lies in its ability to reveal the hidden artistry of the landscape.

13. Travel when you can

All the photos I shared in this article were taken while traveling – and unless you are lucky enough to live in a breathtaking area, it's likely that, like me, you need to travel to find inspiring landscapes to photograph.

Even if you do live somewhere with spectacular landscapes, traveling will expand your experiences and add depth to your portfolio. All my favorite landscape photos were taken while traveling, and the two activities really do go together very well – travel is more interesting and exciting when there's a purpose behind it. Landscape photography can give you that purpose.

Without travel, I would never have experienced and photographed places like this (taken in Bolivia):

At the same time, I recognize that traveling is costly and time-consuming. So even if you can't travel, try to cultivate a traveling mindset – where you see the world around you with fresh, new eyes. Tackle more familiar scenes with this newfound excitement (and you'll be amazed by what you start to see!).

14. Edit your black and white landscape images

If you want to create stunning black and white images, post-processing is crucial. Photographing in RAW is a wise choice, as it gives you more control and flexibility when editing. Don't just press the “Convert to Black and White” button; explore various conversion options to see what best fits your vision.

When converting to black and white, try adjusting individual color channels. This allows you to emphasize or de-emphasize different parts of the image, helping you create a visually engaging photograph. Play with the highlights and shadows, add contrast, tweak clarity, and even apply a vignette to guide the viewer's eye toward your main subject.

Editing software like Adobe Lightroom or Photoshop offers several good black and white conversion methods. Don't hesitate to experiment and find what works best for your particular shot. Spend time on this. The conversion from color to black and white isn't just a technical step; it's an artistic one. This is where your creativity shines, and it's how you can transform a good photo into a masterpiece.

Black and white landscape photography: final words

Black and white landscape photography is an exciting and rewarding pursuit. Whether it's the drama of textured clouds or the intimacy of a detailed close-up shot, the world of monochrome offers endless creative possibilities.

Remember to plan around the weather, take time to edit your shots carefully, and invest in the right gear. Practice capturing different scenes and subjects, and don't hesitate to experiment with your settings.

It's all about capturing the essence of the landscape and making it your own. Embrace the challenge and enjoy the journey into the timeless world of black and white. Whether you're a beginner or have some experience, there's always something new to learn and discover.

So get outside. Give black and white shooting a try. It's a new way of seeing the world – and one that can be a lot of fun.

In the last handful of weeks, Tamron has announced not one, but two powerful new lenses. First came the 35-150mm f/2-2.8 Di III VXD (for Nikon Z-mount) , followed by the upgraded version of the existing 70-180mm f/2.8 Di III VC VXD (for Sony E-mount) .

While Tamron is primarily known for developing enthusiast lenses that combine excellent optics, compact designs, and reasonable prices, the two just-announced lenses will likely occupy a position in the upper echelons of the company's lens lineup – assuming earlier versions of the products are indicative of what's to come.

The Tamron 35-150mm f/2-2.8 Di III VXD for Nikon Z-mount

The original Tamron 35-150mm f/2-2.8 was released back in 2021 for Sony E-mount, and the new product, this time compatible with Nikon's entire array of mirrorless cameras , appears to match its specifications. Like the E-mount version, the new lens promises outstanding optics, not to mention an incredible focal-length range that'll instantly take you from a wide-angle view all the way into a tight telephoto crop .

As the Sony version proved, the lens will be useful for a host of photographers. It should be popular among serious portrait snappers (who can use the lens to capture a wide variety of portrait types within a single session), travel photographers (to shoot landscapes, travel portraits, and everything in between), and professional event photographers (who can use the lens to alternate between scene-setting photos and tighter compositions).

The maximum aperture , which goes all the way to f/2 on the wide end, should appeal to a couple of types of photographers, including shooters who often work indoors and at night as well as portraitists seeking that beautiful background bokeh .

Of course, a do-everything lens like this one does come with drawbacks. The 35-150mm is large, heavy, and expensive. While the MSRP for the Nikon version hasn't been revealed yet, the Sony version comes with an $1899 price tag.

As a result, the lens likely won't see much use from beginners as well as certain minimalistic travel shooters. For others, however, the heft and cost are the sacrifices you make if you want to work with one of the most versatile and effective lenses on the market. Therefore, I recommend Nikon pros and semi-pros take a good look at this lens – especially if you frequently work in low-light scenarios.

The Tamron 70-180mm f/2.8 Di III VC VXD G2

Tamron's more recent announcement, the 70-180mm f/2.8 G2, is arguably even more exciting. It's not an existing lens with a converted mount but instead comes as the upgraded version of the first-generation 70-180mm f/2.8 Di III VC VXD , an E-mount lens that hit the shelves back in 2020.

The new version of the 70-180mm looks to perfect its predecessor's already excellent feature set . Like the original, you can expect outstanding low-light performance thanks to the f/2.8 maximum aperture, an impressively compact design, and a focal-length range that's already much-loved by landscape photographers, portrait photographers, event photographers, and more.

Note that the old 70-180mm f/2.8 is only 20mm shorter than the standard 70-200mm f/2.8 lenses offered by Sony. Yet it's far more compact, making it ideal for travel photography and general walkaround shooting. It's also available for a much cheaper $1099; as a result, it appeals to serious hobbyists as well as professionals. The upgraded version may cost more, but I doubt the price will rise significantly.

In addition to the features mentioned above, what will the new lens offer? For one, the 70-180mm will now include image stabilization technology – Tamron calls this “VC,” or “Vibration Compensation” – which should dramatically improve sharpness when handholding at slow shutter speeds. This will be invaluable for wedding and event photographers working in low light and should also come in handy for landscape and wildlife snappers who prefer to capture tighter images without a tripod.

The lens will boast upgraded autofocus capabilities to ensure even greater speed and accuracy when photographing moving subjects, such as sports and birds in flight; it also sports a “revamped optical design” that “delivers truly superb performance at all focal lengths.” Considering that the original optic lens's optics were well-received by professionals and critics, this should only serve to improve the lens further.

Tamron zoom lens announcements: final words

While we don't yet know when the new lenses will debut – Tamron's official press releases only state “Fall 2023” – you shouldn't have long to wait, and if you're a Nikon Z-mount or Sony E-mount shooter seeking a highly versatile zoom, these are lenses you don't want to miss. If you're ready to become a bokeh master, then let's get started!

What is bokeh in photography?

Bokeh refers to the out-of-focus areas of an image, especially areas that are heavily blurred. It appears as characteristic rounded shapes in the background of photos.

Many professional photographers use this bokeh effect in their images; it helps the main subject stand out, plus it can add an element of artistry to the overall shot. Portrait photographers often rely on creamy background bokeh to elevate their compositions, but you can also find heavy use of bokeh in wildlife photography, product photography, food photography, and event photography.

Note that, generally speaking, the term “bokeh” refers to any background (or foreground) blur in an image. So you can get beautiful bokeh (when the out-of-focus areas are smooth and stunning), or you can get bad bokeh (when the out-of-focus areas are too detailed or appear jagged). Later on in this article, I'll explain what causes good versus bad bokeh, but for now, just know that not all bokeh looks equally gorgeous.

The 5 factors determining the bokeh effect in your photos

Beginners often struggle to capture lovely bokeh effects, and it's because bokeh can be complicated ; it's not as simple as adjusting one setting on your camera and calling it a day.

Instead, the bokeh quality in your photos is influenced by five factors:

  1. Aperture size (ie, the size of the hole in the lens that lets in light)
  2. Lens choice
  3. Distance between the camera and your subject
  4. Distance between the subject and the background
  5. Quality of the background

Let's look at each factor in turn, starting with:

1. Aperture size

The aperture is a hole in the lens, and the size corresponds to your camera's f-number setting.

A low f-number such as f/1.8 or f/2.8 will give you a wide aperture, while a high f-number such as f/11 or f/16 will give you a narrow aperture. Ultimately, a wide aperture will create a better bokeh effect – because the wider the aperture, the more background blur the lens will produce.

A narrow aperture, on the other hand, produces images that are sharp from foreground to background; that's why landscape photographers nearly always shoot at f/8 and beyond. They want everything in focus!

So when you see beautiful bokeh images, they're generally produced at f/4 and wider (and most are produced at f/2.8, f/1.8, or even f/1.2).

Unfortunately, not all lenses allow you to shoot at ultra-wide apertures, as I explain below:

2. Lens choice

Certain lenses produce beautiful, creamy bokeh. Other lenses are rather underwhelming in their bokeh quality.为什么？

It has to do with several factors.

First, the larger the lens's maximum aperture, the better the bokeh quality. As discussed above, if you can open your lens's aperture really wide, the bokeh will look great – whereas a closed-down aperture will produce nervous, distracting bokeh that doesn't complement the subject.

Second, some lenses offer more circular apertures, whereas other lenses have hexagonal, septagonal, or octagonal apertures. Because aperture shape generally determines the shape of the bokeh, the more circular the aperture, the smoother the bokeh effect.

(Note that aperture shape is primarily determined by the aperture blade count, which you can find on the specification sheet of every lens. More blades equal a more circular aperture, which in turn corresponds to more pleasing bokeh. Got it?)

Third, the longer the lens, the more it compresses the background, and the blurrier the background becomes. With bokeh, longer equals better .

So for the best bokeh, purchase a lens with a long focal length (eg, 200mm), a wide maximum aperture (eg, f/2.8), and plenty of aperture blades (9+).

3. Distance between the camera and your subject

As you get closer to your subject, the background bokeh effect will magnify – and as you step away from your subject, the bokeh effect will disappear.

So the closer you get, the better the bokeh effect.

Now, you can get close to your subject in two ways:

You can move toward them physically and literally bring the lens close.

Or you can use a telephoto lens with a 300mm, 400mm, or even 800mm focal length. These lenses will zoom right up to your subject (and you don't have to change your position).

The telephoto lens option is often convenient, especially if you're working with skittish subjects (eg, birds and wildlife). But sometimes it's nice to get up close and personal, especially if you're going for a more intimate perspective (as I often recommend for portrait photography ).

4. Distance between the subject and the background

If your background is close to your subject, it will be less blurred – and hence the bokeh effect will be weaker.

But if your background is far from your subject, it will be more blurred, and will generally look very nice.

Say you're photographing a child in front of a tree. If you put them just in front of the tree (so the bark touches their back), both the child and the tree will be in focus, and you'll get very little bokeh to speak of. But if you bring the child out and away from the tree, the bark will begin to blur.

In fact, increasing the subject-background distance is one of the easiest ways to create better bokeh, especially if you don't own a wide-aperture lens. The farther your subject moves from the background, the more beautiful the result.

5. Quality of the background

Some backgrounds are easy to blur, and other backgrounds are much more difficult.

This often works as you'd expect, where uniform elements (eg, a forest of green leaves) create very smooth bokeh, while messy, jagged elements (eg, a crowd of people, cars, and houses) create very distracting bokeh.

But there are other background qualities to consider, too.

For instance, if you compose your image so that the light shines through an area of the background, you'll often capture stunning bokeh effects. That's how you can get a shot like this one:

Do you see how the light from the sky shines through the leaves in the background? It creates a very well-defined, circular bokeh effect, which a lot of photographers love .

Bokeh photography factors: putting it all together

The five factors I discussed above work together to achieve optimal bokeh quality.

So even if you can't adjust one factor (eg, lens quality), you can still adjust other factors to get a nice result.

Of course, the best bokeh effect comes from maximizing each and every one of the factors discussed above, though this isn't always feasible. Sometimes, you need a narrow aperture for an unrelated reason, or you need the subject to stay close to the background, or you can't get close, etc. And that's where you'll need to consider the other bokeh factors and work with the ones you can control.

Bokeh and sensor size

Have you ever wondered how the size of your camera's sensor affects bokeh? You're not alone! Many photographers, especially when choosing a new camera, want to know if there's a link between sensor size and beautiful background bokeh.

Let's start with the basics. If you compare side-by-side images from APS-C and full-frame cameras, both using 50mm lenses, you'll notice that the photos are different. The image from the APS-C camera will look tighter, while the full-frame image will be wider. This difference is not because of the sensor's inherent properties but rather because the smaller sensor effectively crops the image.

Technically, the images reaching the back of the camera will be identical, but as they're captured by the sensor, the APS-C file gets cropped. This means that the depth of field (the area in focus) will match perfectly in both files, even though the APS-C image appears tighter. To achieve the same composition as the full-frame image, the APS-C camera would need to be moved forward several feet.

So what's the bottom line? The larger the sensor size, the better the bokeh will look in a similar composition. It's not a property inherent to larger sensors but a result of the internal cropping that happens with smaller sensors. Understanding this will help you get the most out of your camera, no matter the sensor size.

How to achieve nice bokeh: the step-by-step process

I've already explained the theory behind good bokeh, but in this section, I'd like to share, in practical terms, how to get the best possible bokeh for any given situation.

Step 1: Use the right lens

Bokeh starts with lens choice. Go for a lens with a wide maximum aperture (ideally, f/2.8 or wider, but f/4 can work, too).

If possible, pick a lens with a high number of aperture blades (remember: the more circular the aperture shape, the better!).

And go with a standard or telephoto focal length, not wide angle.

2. Select a large aperture

Bokeh is only affected by one camera setting: the aperture. So make it count!

For the strongest bokeh effect, dial in your lens's lowest f-number. (Though if your lens goes to f/1.2 or f/1.4 and you're shooting from up close, you may want to narrow the aperture just a bit to prevent your subject from going out of focus.)

If you're not sure how to adjust the aperture, by the way, consult your camera manual. You'll generally need to shift the mode dial to Manual mode or Aperture Priority mode , then rotate the corresponding aperture dial until it gives you the result you want (though some lenses offer an aperture ring on the barrel, which you can turn to manually set the aperture).

3. Get close to your subject

Determine the subject you want to photograph, then get close. Remember, you can either move close physically, or you can use a long lens for a tighter perspective.

If you have the time, try both; the effect will be slightly different in each case (longer lenses compress the background, which gives smooth bokeh, but you may lose a bit of intimacy), and you may find you prefer one look over the other.

4. Position your subject for the best background

If you can move your subject (or, in the case of portraits, if you can ask your subject to move), then put them in front of a uniform, non-distracting background.

And bring them far away from the background, so the bokeh effect is more pronounced.

If you can't move your subject, then try to adjust your perspective . By getting down low, you can remove distracting background details from the frame; by moving to the side, you can increase subject-background distance;等等。

5. Dial in your remaining settings for a good exposure

At this point, you've done everything you can for the best-possible bokeh.

So determine the remaining settings you need for a good exposure (eg, your shutter speed and your ISO ). Focus on your subject. Check one last time to ensure the background doesn't include any distractions.

And take your photo!

After you capture a shot or two, check your camera's LCD. Pay careful attention to the quality of the background. Ask yourself: How does the bokeh look? Is there anything I can change to make it better?

Make the necessary changes, then shoot again.

Tips and tricks for creating beautiful bokeh effects

Looking to take your bokeh to the next level? Here are a few of my top tips to really elevate that creamy background blur:

1. Shoot during the golden hours

Golden hour lighting is a magical time for photographers, and it can add a special touch to your bokeh photography. The term refers to the hour just after sunrise or before sunset when the sun bathes everything in a warm, soft light; the warm light casts a wonderful glow on backgrounds, which looks simply stunning when rendered as bokeh.

One of the techniques you can try during the golden hour is backlighting. Positioning your subject between the camera and the sun can create a luminous effect that makes the bokeh look extraordinary. Experiment with different angles and lighting positions; you'll often be rewarded with some truly breathtaking images.

And if you've never taken photos during the golden hour before, don't worry! There are plenty of apps and websites that can tell you exactly when the golden hour occurs in your location. With a bit of practice and an eye for lighting, you'll find that the golden hour is one of the most beautiful times to create eye-catching bokeh.

2. Try using a macro lens

Macro lenses encourage you to shoot up close, and this can result in some truly breathtaking bokeh photography. As I explained above, the closer you are to your subject, the better the bokeh usually appears – so because macro lenses have this unique ability to focus on subjects that are very close, they open up a whole new world of creative possibilities.

You can use a macro lens and dial in an ultra-wide aperture to create a very narrow window of sharpness. This allows for creamy background bokeh, paving the way for soft-focus images of flowers, plants, insects, and more. If you haven't tried this before, you're in for a treat!

Choosing the right macro lens for your camera system can be a fun exploration. Look for one that offers a wide aperture and suitable focal length for your subjects. Experimenting with different lenses and settings can lead to some surprising and delightful results!

3. Make sure to focus carefully

Focusing accurately is one of the most crucial aspects of creating captivating bokeh photography. When you're working with a shallow depth of field, the margin for error in focusing is slim. If your focus is even slightly off, it can ruin the image, causing the main subject to go out of focus.

To avoid this issue, you'll want to be very deliberate in where you set your focus. Using autofocus can sometimes lead to errors, especially if you're close to your subject. Manual focus can give you more control.

Regardless, start by choosing the point of focus carefully. If you're photographing a person, for example, focusing on the eyes is usually a good strategy. Use your camera's zoom-in feature in Live View mode to really hone in on the focus point and adjust it as needed (either manually or using your camera's autofocus).

Practicing is key. Try working with different subjects at different distances, and use both autofocus and manual focus to see what works best for you. Over time, you'll develop a feel for getting it just right. You'll find that the effort is well worth it, as the precise focus will make your bokeh photography truly stand out.

4. Create some bokeh abstracts

Bokeh isn't just a beautiful background effect; it can also be the main subject of a photo. In my experience, you can use bokeh to capture abstract images that are both mysterious and visually appealing. The process of creating bokeh abstracts is creative, fun, and a little unconventional.

You'll need a subject with small points of light, like Christmas lights, car headlights, or fairy lights. Wait until it's dark out or find a dark room, and then dial in a wide aperture on your lens. You'll also want to switch your lens over to manual focus.

Now, here's where it gets interesting: Deliberately focus in front of your subject. This will cause the pinpricks of light to turn into soft, glowing orbs, creating the bokeh effect. You can experiment with different angles, distances, and focus points to see how the appearance of the bokeh is changed.

Bokeh abstracts are a fantastic way to explore your creativity. You can display them on their own, or you can combine these abstract patterns with other elements or use them as backgrounds in composite images. No two bokeh abstracts are the same, so don't be afraid to experiment and find your own unique style.

5. Create custom bokeh shapes

Adding custom bokeh shapes to your images is a creative way to personalize your photography, and it's easier than you might think. This technique allows you to transform ordinary bokeh orbs into various shapes like hearts, stars, or even letters.

First, you'll need to cut out a lens-sized piece of paper, then cut out a custom shape within that piece. Place the paper directly on top of your front lens element (like a filter), and make sure to use a wide aperture. Finally, identify a subject that can produce strong bokeh (such as fairy lights), adjust the focus until the subject becomes a background blur, and start shooting!

实验是这里的关键。 Play around with the size and shape of your cutout, the distance to your subject, and your focus settings. You might need to adjust and tweak things to get the results you want.

The beauty of custom bokeh shapes is that they add a unique flair to your photos and can be tailored to fit the theme of your image. Whether it's hearts for a romantic portrait or stars for a magical night scene, custom bokeh shapes offer endless possibilities for creativity.

Remember to be patient and enjoy the process. It may take some trial and error, but once you master this technique, you'll be over the moon.

So while bokeh is great, and while I highly recommend you learn to create a nice bokeh effect, don't get so obsessed that you use it all the time!

How to get a bokeh effect: final words

Hopefully, you now feel ready to head out with your camera and capture some stunning bokeh.

Just remember to choose the right lens, adjust your camera settings, position yourself well, and pick the right background.

Pretty soon, you'll be shooting bokeh like a pro!

您想捕捉孩子奔跑、鸟类飞翔、运动员扣篮、街头瞬间等动作镜头吗？

好吧，你可以——如果你知道如何使用相机的连拍模式的话。

连拍模式也称为连拍模式，可让您不间断地拍摄一系列连拍图像。根据相机的功能，您可以每秒记录 5、10、20 甚至 60 张图像，每张图像都提供了捕捉一生一次的动作图像的机会。

在本文中，我将分享像专业人士一样使用连拍模式所需的一切，从基础知识一直到高级连拍指南。

让我们开始吧。

什么是突发模式？

连拍模式是一种相机功能，可让您快速连续拍摄一系列照片。激活连拍模式后，您可以按住快门按钮，您的相机将连续拍摄一组照片。

具体连拍模式速度因相机而异；低端和老式相机提供每秒 3 帧范围的连拍模式（即每秒 3 张照片）。一流的运动相机提供每秒 20、30 或 60 帧的速度。普通相机每秒可拍摄 6-12 帧。

不幸的是，大多数相机连拍模式并不是无限的。当您拍照时，相机的缓冲区（图像在添加到存储卡之前存储的位置）会被填满。一旦缓冲区已满，您的连拍模式将停止工作（至少直到缓冲区释放空间，此时您可以再次开始连拍）。

拍摄低质量图像或使用顶级相机时也有例外，但一般来说，如果您按住相机的连拍模式，它最终会冻结。

高速连续与低速连续

许多相机提供多种连拍模式（或速度），特定模式的可用性取决于几个因素。

您选择的自动对焦可以发挥作用。与 AF-C 相比，AF-S 往往可以实现更快的连拍速度。文件的质量和大小也很重要；如果您拍摄的是 JPEG、压缩的 RAW 文件或裁剪的文件，您可能能够以更高的速度进行拍摄。您使用的快门类型也会影响速度，但我稍后会深入研究。

现在，您可能会看到两种连拍速度，通常标记为“高速连续”和“低速连续”。与低速连拍相比，高速连拍通常每秒会多提供一些帧，但从实际角度来看，有什么区别呢？换句话说，您如何选择一种模式而不是另一种模式？

如果您正在处理超快速的动作，例如赛车或飞翔的鸟，那么选择更高速度的选项至关重要。否则，低速连拍可能就足够了。请记住，关键在于将速度与拍摄对象相匹配，以创造出完美的镜头。

什么时候应该使用突发模式？

从技术上讲，您可以一直使用突发模式。假设您在任何时候都没有按住快门按钮太长时间，则每次发现新的拍摄对象时都可以拍摄一系列图像。

不过，我不建议你经常使用连拍模式。其一，这会鼓励你在摄影上变得懒惰——你会连拍，而且你永远不会学会如何为构图精美的图像计时。另外，持续突发模式会产生大量文件。你的存储卡会很快被填满，你的硬盘也会如此。

相反，我建议当您知道自己正在拍摄动作或即将看到千载难逢的时刻时，打开连拍模式。

例如，如果您正在拍摄体育比赛，您可能会在整个事件中保持连拍模式；这样，每当发生有趣的事情时——扣篮、失误、压哨绝杀——你就准备好捕捉重要时刻。如果您要拍摄快速移动的野生动物或鸟类、儿童的足球比赛或进行敏捷训练的狗，情况也是如此。

连拍模式也非常适合捕捉不容错过的时刻（即使它们不涉及动作）。如果您要拍摄您的孩子在毕业典礼上走过舞台，连拍模式几乎可以保证拍摄到他们接受毕业证书的照片。如果您正在拍摄肖像主题，连拍模式将增加您捕捉到令人回味的表情或姿势的机会。如果您正在拍摄街景，连拍模式将帮助您记录瞬间的互动，例如配偶的目光接触。

顺便说一句，您还可以使用连拍摄影来捕捉技术上困难的场景。如果您以高倍率手动对焦花朵，则可以在缓慢调整焦点时发出一系列图像，并且更有可能获得良好的结果。

以下是定期使用连拍模式的摄影类型列表：

  • 体育摄影
  • 宠物摄影
  • 鸟类摄影
  • 野生动物摄影
  • 街头摄影（有时）
  • 活动摄影（有时）

如何使用突发模式（逐步）

现在您已经熟悉了突发模式的定义和重要性，让我们看看如何使用它来获得最佳结果。

第 1 步：激活相机上的连拍模式

激活连拍模式取决于您的相机（不同型号的相机可能有所不同，因此不要假设同一品牌甚至同一系列的所有相机都是相同的）。

一般来说，您需要寻找“驾驶”菜单或“拍摄”模式菜单。有些相机提供专用的拍摄模式转盘（某些富士胶片型号上有此功能），而其他相机提供拍摄模式按钮（一些奥林巴斯相机具有其中之一），还有一些相机需要菜单潜水来调整拍摄模式。

找到“拍摄”模式菜单后，您需要选择“连续”或“连续高”选项，有时表示为多个堆叠帧（请参阅佳能 5D Mark II 显示屏右下角的图标）：

如果您尝试激活连拍模式但失败，请查阅相机手册或在线查看。

第二步：选择相应的对焦模式

启用连拍模式后，您还需要设置正确的对焦模式。对于动作摄影，最好使用相机的连续对焦模式，在佳能上称为 AI Servo，在大多数其他相机品牌（包括尼康和索尼）上称为 AF-C。即使您按住快门按钮，连续对焦也会持续跟踪移动的物体，从而有助于在拍摄对象在场景中移动并捕捉连拍图像时保持清晰的对焦。

或者，如果您已经构图但想要保证一个好的姿势、一个美丽的时刻等，我建议您使用相机的单次自动对焦模式，在佳能上称为 One-Shot，在佳能上称为 AF-S大多数其他品牌。只需半按快门按钮即可锁定对焦，然后当拍摄对象进入画面时，完全按下快门按钮即可进行连拍。

第 3 步：仔细选择您的设置

最后，您需要根据您的拍摄情况调整正确的相机设置。虽然这些会因场景而异，但请确保您的快门速度相对较快；否则，您最终会得到模糊的照片（或者，如果您的快门速度非常慢，则相机的连拍模式将无法正常工作）。我建议以 1/250 秒及以上的速度拍摄移动较慢的物体，以 1/1000 秒及以上的速度拍摄移动较快的物体。

如果您难以获得所需的快门速度，请尝试扩大光圈或提高ISO 。

第 4 步：捕捉连拍图像

现在乐趣开始了！一旦找到值得拍摄的主题，按住快门按钮，相机就会连拍照片。

正如我上面所解释的，在使用突发模式时表现出克制非常重要；否则，您的相机缓冲区将被填满，您将错过关键时刻。因此，等到一张好照片开始出现时（如果您使用单次自动对焦，通常应该提前锁定焦点），然后完全按下快门按钮来拍摄完美的照片。

连拍和快门类型

现代相机提供两种类型的快门：机械快门和电子快门。单反相机主要使用机械快门，当您按下快门按钮时，物理机制会揭开或覆盖相机传感器。这是一种已经存在了数十年的可靠方法。

但近年来，无反光镜相机已转向电子快门。借助这项技术，按下快门按钮时传感器会自动曝光照片，从而无需机械元件。这是一项重大进步，提供了一些明显的优势，但也存在潜在的缺点。

首先是优点：电子快门通常比机械快门更快，这意味着您可以以 1/40000 秒等快得难以置信的快门速度进行拍摄，并且连拍速度也得到提高。

电子快门也安静得多，甚至是无声的，这对事件摄影产生了巨大的影响。想象一下在教堂举行一场安静的仪式，比如婚礼；得益于近乎静音的电子快门，您可以不间断地拍摄，而不必担心分散与会者的注意力。此外，由于需要处理的机械磨损有限，因此电子快门的使用寿命往往比机械快门更长。

然而，正如我提到的，电子快门确实有一个缺点：卷帘快门效应。基本上，电子快门会逐条曝光传感器的线条，因此如果曝光过程足够慢并且拍摄对象快速移动，则最终拍摄的照片可能会显示出扭曲的拍摄对象。好消息是，相机制造商在加速曝光过程方面做得越来越好，一些现代无反光镜相机在防止或减少滚动快门方面做得很好！

因此，当您需要闪电般的拍摄速度时，电子快门通常是一个不错的选择。但如果您要拍摄动作，尤其是画面中快速移动的物体，请确保使用旨在消除卷帘快门效果的电子快门进行拍摄，或者切换到机械快门。

注意：了解何时使用每种快门类型会对您的摄影产生重大影响，因此不要害怕尝试并看看什么最适合您！

使用相机连拍模式的提示

想要改进连拍模式拍摄吗？以下是一些帮助您提升图像水平的实用技巧：

1.不要敲击快门按钮

连拍模式功能强大，但要获得最佳效果，您需要小心操作快门按钮。使用连拍模式时，很容易用力按下按钮，但这实际上会导致相机抖动导致模糊增加。

相反，轻轻按下快门按钮，就像手指从其表面滚动一样。

这种轻柔触摸背后的想法是尽可能消除振动。当您以较慢的快门速度或以高倍率拍摄时，这一点变得尤其重要。可以把它想象成拿着一杯装满水的水——任何突然的动作都可能导致溢出。通过巧妙地处理快门按钮，您可以减少照片“溢出”的可能性，从而保持图像锐利清晰。

2. 思考你的作文

虽然动作摄影的兴奋和连拍模式的使用可能会引起您对快门速度和时机的注意，但构图仍然是创造令人惊叹的图像的关键因素。您可能认为捕捉完美瞬间就是一切，但如何捕捉这一瞬间也同样重要。

拍摄时，必须问自己：每个元素应该放置在哪里才能产生最大的影响？框架中的物体之间有什么关系？

即使在快节奏的拍摄中，三分法则等指导原则也可以帮助您的构图。同样，空间规则，包括在拍摄对象移动或观看的方向上留出空间，可以为您的镜头增添活力。

请记住，每一个镜头，即使是瞬间拍摄的镜头，都会讲述一个故事。通过考虑构图，确保您的故事在视觉上引人注目——即使在使用连拍模式时也是如此。

3.带足够的存储卡

连续拍摄模式将比您想象的更快地填满您的存储卡。想象一下以 10 FPS 的速度拍摄一分钟。您最终将获得多达 600 张照片！因此，如果您打算捕捉动作并使用连拍模式，请务必携带足够的存储卡。

我建议使用存储卡盒并装满 64 GB（或更大）的卡。每当您计划拍摄动作时，请随身携带整套设备。这就像为长途旅行准备额外的电池一样；你永远不知道什么时候会需要它们，但手头有它们可能会成为你的救星。

连拍模式是一项令人兴奋的功能，它开辟了新的摄影可能性，但如果没有足够的存储空间，您可能会发现自己错过了令人难以置信的时刻。确保您有足够的装备来应对连续射击的刺激和强度！

4. 在良好光线下拍摄以获得最大清晰度

我们都知道光线在摄影中的重要性，但在捕捉动作时，光线变得更加重要。光线越低，快门速度越慢，导致图像更柔和、清晰度更低。即使使用连拍模式，光线不足也会导致令人失望的结果。

为了获得真正清晰的照片，您需要保持较快的快门速度 - 为此，您需要良好的照明。黄金时段，即日出后或日落前不久，非常适合拍摄光线充足的照片。中午也会有强烈的光线，但要小心，因为这种光线可能很刺眼且不讨人喜欢。

如果您发现自己需要在弱光下拍摄，提高 ISO 而不是降低快门速度可能是一个可行的选择。它可能会增加图像中的可见噪点，但一点点噪点比模糊的混乱更好。

5.在弱光下使用连拍模式

虽然在良好的光线下拍摄是理想的选择，但有时您会发现自己在昏暗的条件下工作。在这些情况下，连拍模式实际上可以成为您获得更清晰镜头的盟友。

当您按下快门按钮时，会产生可能导致模糊的振动。你按得越用力，相机震动就越大。连拍模式可以最大程度地减少此问题，因为每次连拍只需按一次快门按钮。连拍模式系列中的后续图像可能比第一张图像更清晰。

认为连拍模式（通常与动作和体育摄影相关）在弱光条件下可以派上用场，这似乎有悖常理。但了解这一原理可以在光线不配合时节省拍摄时间。

摄影中的连拍模式：最后的话

现在您已经完成了本文，您已经了解了连拍摄影的全部内容，以及它如何提高您的拍摄效果。

所以花一些时间测试一下。找到一个动作主题，并享受连发射击的乐趣。您将更好地使用连拍模式，并且您将开始了解相机的功能和限制。
